cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as a group of concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. The Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Astral Above Elemental Below
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them, are the Inner Planes.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them. Bytopia is an Upper Plane positioned between Mount Celestia and Elysium on the Great Wheel.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Bytopia
planes.philosophicalEssence: Personal achievement alongside social interdependence. Bytopia is the heaven of productive work and the satisfaction of a job well done.
planes.emotionalInfluence: The goodness flowing through the plane creates feelings of goodwill and happiness in creatures dwelling there.

physicalProperties.shape: Two layers whose surfaces face each other like the covers of a closed book, approximately one mile apart. Looking up from Dothion, the top layer, a traveler can see Shurrock overhead.

temperature.description: Dothion has pastoral, temperate conditions. Shurrock has rough country and harsh weather.

physicalProperties.weatherPatterns: Dothion has mild pastoral weather. Shurrock experiences harsh weather conditions.

layers.name: Dothion
layers.description: Farms nestled among well-tamed woods are hubs of pastoral activity and individual industry. Dothion is the 'top' layer of Bytopia and rewards those who seek a quiet life.
layers.environmentalDescription: Farms nestled among well-tamed woods are hubs of pastoral activity and individual industry.

layers.name: Shurrock
layers.description: Small communities thrive around quarries and mills amid rough country and harsh weather. Shurrock is the paradise of those who continually challenge and better themselves.
layers.environmentalDescription: Small communities thrive around quarries and mills amid rough country and harsh weather.

timeFlow.description: Time flows normally on Bytopia as is typical for Outer Planes unless specific effects intervene. Distance is virtually meaningless on the Outer Planes; a perceptible region might seem small on one visit and stretch to infinity on another.

environmentalEffects.name: Goodwill and Happiness
environmentalEffects.description: The goodness flowing through the plane creates feelings of goodwill and happiness in creatures dwelling there.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: The goodness flowing through the plane creates feelings of goodwill and happiness in creatures dwelling there. This is a DM-directed environmental effect referenced in chapter 3 Environmental Effects.
environmentalEffects.emotionalEffect: Feelings of goodwill and happiness pervade creatures dwelling on Bytopia.

environmentalEffects.name: Mirrored Reactions Between Layers
environmentalEffects.description: Every action carried out on one layer has repercussions on the other—an equal and opposite reaction, though more metaphorical than physical.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Every action carried out on one layer of Bytopia has repercussions on the other layer—an equal and opposite reaction, described as more metaphorical than physical. This can be used as a narrative tool to challenge characters to recognize the impact their actions have on the world.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on Bytopia, a Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw because Bytopia is an Upper Plane and opposed to its nature.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: The d4 penalty is cumulative with each failed save. After multiple failed saves the creature subtracts multiple d4s from D20 Tests.
onFailure.duration: Until the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature

onSuccess.description: The creature avoids gaining an additional cumulative d4 penalty to D20 Tests.

savingThrow.repeatSaveTiming: After finishing each Long Rest on Bytopia
savingThrow.recoveryTrigger: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature
recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is not an Upper Plane (for Fiends)

planarDissonance.description: Fiends who visit Bytopia (an Upper Plane) experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on Bytopia, a Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

adventureThemes: Recognizing the impact of one's actions by witnessing mirrored reactions on the opposite layer
The satisfaction of productive work and a job well done
Challenging characters to see the consequences of their deeds

crossReferences.description: Chapter 3: Environmental Effects - referenced for goodwill and happiness effect on Bytopia

planarTravelMethods.name: Astral Color Pool to Bytopia
planarTravelMethods.description: An amber-colored pool in the Astral Plane leads to Bytopia. Color pools appear as two-dimensional pools of rippling colors, 1d6 × 10 feet in diameter.

planarTravelMethods.name: Tradegate Gate-Town
planarTravelMethods.description: Tradegate is the gate-town in the Outlands that contains a portal leading to Bytopia. Each gate-town shares many of the characteristics of the plane where its gate leads.
requirements: Travel to Tradegate in the Outlands

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Travel Spells
planarTravelMethods.description: Spells such as Gate and Plane Shift can directly transport adventurers to Bytopia.
requirements: Ability to cast the appropriate spell
Proper tuning fork for Plane Shift

globalPlanarDissonance.description: Celestials who visit the Lower Planes and Fiends who visit the Upper Planes experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to its nature, a Celestial or Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on a plane alien to the creature's nature

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: The d4 subtraction is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.duration: Until the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature

onSuccess.description: The creature avoids gaining an additional cumulative d4 penalty.

savingThrow.repeatSaveTiming: After finishing each Long Rest on the opposed plane
savingThrow.recoveryTrigger: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is not opposed to the creature's nature
recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane not opposed to the creature's nature

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
